# Reference

<!-- DO NOT EDIT: This document was generated by Puppet Strings -->

## Table of Contents

### Classes

* [`nfs_exports`](#nfs_exports): manage entries in /etc/exports

### Defined types

* [`nfs_exports::export`](#nfs_exportsexport): fully manage an entry in /etc/exports

## Classes

### `nfs_exports`

Along with a defined type (nfs::exports::export) manages
entries in /etc/exports and subsequently invokes exportfs.

class { '::nfs_exports':
  exports => {
    '/data'     => [
      { client => 'testvm.example.com', options => ['rw'] },
      { client => 'roclient.example.com', options => ['ro'] },
    ],
  },
}

#### Examples

##### Class usage

```puppet

```

#### Parameters

The following parameters are available in the `nfs_exports` class.

##### `etc_exports`

Data type: `String`

path to file to apply changes to (/etc/exports)

##### `exportfs`

Data type: `String`

command to invoke after changes to exports file

##### `exportfs_path`

Data type: `Array[String]`

passed to the exec used to invoke exportfs

##### `exports`

Data type: `Hash[String,Array[Struct[{
    client  => String,
    options => Optional[Variant[String,Array[String]]]
  }]]]`

hash with index of the path of the export, and a key
consisting of an array of client structs, see below for example

Default value: `{}`

## Defined types

### `nfs_exports::export`

Manages one export entry in /etc/exports,
completelely replacing any existing hosts for that entry.

nfs_exports::export { '/data':
  clients => [
    { client => '-', options => ['ro'] },
    { client => 'example.com'},
    { client => 'other.example.com', options => 'rw'},
 ],
}
should produce:
  /data -ro example.com other.example.com(rw)

#### Examples

##### Typical usage

```puppet

```

#### Parameters

The following parameters are available in the `nfs_exports::export` defined type.

##### `clients`

Data type: `Array[Struct[{
    client  => String,
    options => Optional[Variant[String,Array[String]]]
  }]]`

struct containing a client string (netgroup, ip address, etc.)
and an optional options array.  If the client is - it is treated
as a defaults entry and the options are not enclosed in parenthesis
see the exports man page on your system for details

Default value: `[]`
